comments.commentBody:
"Obama is not eligible to be president?"

Ok, you and the 6 people who "liked" this are clearly not from planet earth. The only "erroneous logic" around here is your claim, incorrect on its face, that these children are not citizens and are not eligible to be president. The law is clear - born in the USA, citizen of the USA. If we want to change that, we can, but that's clearly the law on the books, and has been for many generations.

When did your ancestors immigrate here? What was their status? Why do you deserve to be a citizen?

Great! How about  "No-one descended from a person who fought for or swore allegiance to the Confederacy shall be eligible for (insert the public services of your choice" except at a price five times that charged to legal Florida residents"? Or "no-one tracing ancestry to any former resident of New York or Michigan", or "no-one descended from a mother of the Jewish faith", or whatever your particular prejudice happens to be. For the moment my kids can be content with a visit to Disneyland, not that place in Orlando.
Just one more example of the belief system of weird nasty intolerant Republicans who follow the Constitution only when it suits them.  Shameful!

I agree with most of the other comments that the old format was best. I would make one change though, let the reader decide the number of comments per page, 25, 50, 100 or all. It would allow the browser search function to find specific comments or authors.
I signed up for Facebook today to satisfy your requirements. I don't like Facebook either.

Agreed. The Times wins the record for fasted response to a UI disaster (read more).

I am grateful this was fixed so quickly but wonder why the new release wasn't tested. The frustration with truncating comments showed up immediately and could have been addressed before launching.

Thank you for removing the “Read More” function. It is much easier to scroll down and scan comments than to scroll, scan, and click. The Facebook and Twitter sharing functions save time cutting and pasting comments on other platforms.  I also like the use of profile images, even if it’s a flower, a geometric pattern, or any visual cue that indicates a user’s interests or personality. But I cringe when I read about someone losing a job or getting called into the principal’s office because of an intemperate tweet. Anonymity saves tears, especially when one's own words can turn into boomerangs.

I am afraid I must disagree.
There are many with honest and well-considered opinions who do not have the freedom, in a practical sense, to express them candidly in a public forum under their own names, in spite of their personal ideals of open discourse.
For instance, there are many public sector workers who are prevented by work rules from speaking to the press about their jobs, and many professionals with similar restrictions in their contracts.
Many of these may have valuable insights to provide, but need to do so anonymously.
In my own case, as a physician, I could run afoul of my employer by saying the wrong things about the incompetence and shortsightedness of hospital administrators, I could raise the ire of CMMS by criticizing Medicare, under whose rules a typographic error on a billing sheet can be prosecuted as criminal fraud, or I could antagonize current or potential patients by expressing political opinions with which they disagree.
There is also the matter of spambots and data aggregators.
I have been happy to provide my name to NYT writers who have requested it in order to be able to quote me, or when writing letters to the editor, but I prefer not to do so in internet fora.

Eric is absolutely right. In fact, he's precisely the kind of commenter whose input I like because Eric, et al. offer unique professional insights -- insights that we can't get elsewhere.

When some of the op-ed columnists were into reporting for the Fracking News, several civil engineers wrote in, using pseudonyms, to give readers the facts -- as opposed to the columnists' untrained pro-fracking flakking. That kind of professional expertise is invaluable, and who wants to have to go to page 12 of the comments to see if maybe a real expert weighed in? If working people are not allowed to use pseudonyms to become "trusted" (what an insult!), their comments will appear after everyone else's.

BTW, one of the first "trusted" commenters was a Westchester PR firm that writes comments to help its clients. They sent out a press release bragging about their "award." So if -- like me -- you've been commenting regularly & substantively but the Times doesn't "trust" you, well, just consider yourself less worthy than a PR firm subtly shilling for its clients in "response" to a news or analysis item.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com
Some people have personal safety issues that make using pseudonyms and not using Facebook preferable.
I would prefer it if you used Facebook like USA Today has done. If you don't have the guts to back up your post with your real identity,you shouldn't be allowed to post.

Yes, yes, yes!  I sent my negative feelings about this issue early this morning, but the change has not yet been made.  Please, folks, recommend this post so it will come to the editors' attention!  (My post is fairly high in the Readers Picks section, but we obviously need more of you to register your discontent.)  Ben from Cascades, OR, thanks for including it in your list!

You mouse over the Datestamp at bottom left of each post (doesn't really matter which one) and either click the permalink-address that comes up or cut and paste it, either directly into the browser window (or into any text tool) and replace the number with the number you wish to find, hit Return.
Yes it is a bit cumbersome and NYT may eventually provide a tool for it. Alternatively copy & paste the address into some record doc, of those you wish to revisit.

I'd suggest you send big bouquets of flowers, bottles of the best champage, and lifetime subscriptions to the Times to Marie Burns, Karen Garcia, and Kate Madison in appreciation of their contributions to discussions of public policy.  Their insightful comments always added to my understanding of the issues.  If they decide to no longer contribute to the discussion, we are poorer for it.

Me, too. I used to like being able to scroll through the full comments, but I now notice a couple of advantages to the new format. I can get a sense of what the commenter is saying in the four allowed lines and thus scroll through more comments faster, clicking "Read More" only for those that look worth my time. And (this is sly) people are editing their own comments more judiciously to make their points more concisely.

No water? Who needs water... just drink gas.

How dare the Eli family ridicule the gas company. They are there to create jobs, and according to Sarah Palin, feed the energy hungry state.

May be someone will soon find a way to convert human beings, plants, and animals from "100% water dependent creatures" to something that can take "90% water and 10% motor oil consuming creatures".
Criminals!

And for everyone who keeps saying, "They should have hired a lawyer," there were no competent gas attorneys around here until after the gas company lawyers had already gotten people to sign on the dotted line.  Your average small-town attorney had never seen a drilling or leasing contract before the rush.

The company that got mineral rights on our land lied to the property owners.  They claimed that the state would force them to accept a lease whether they wanted it or not (and actually had someone call who claimed to be from the state).  The leasing company claimed that a separate authorization would be required for drilling with thousands and thousands of dollars in compensation, but it's not.  The company told them that it was a 5-year lease, but it's not.  It's 5 years with no drilling.  Once drilling started anywhere in the section, the lease continues as long as wells are operative--in other words, indefinitely.  Every area company drilled at least one well in every section to continue the leases indefinitely.  All I have to say about the drilling companies around here is liar, liar, liar.  The mineral rights owners are getting all kinds of costs deducted.  Beware anything that the companies say.

A stunning - and cruel - policy.  Would  Florida school alumni associations be willing to take this on? Members could pledge to withold financial support or discourage their children's attendance to the schoold (especially folks who are now out of state) as long as this policy is in place.  That might send a pretty strong message to the governor.

Is there any more evidence needed that the US culture harbors an ugly underbelly of cruelty, particularly by actions imposed by our political/corporate leaders to denigrate, coerce, and humiliate average citizens?

They are not undocumented, they are illegal, don't faciltate law breaking with language.  Clearly this is an example of the government going too far, as it affects american citizens.  That does not excuse, however, the children of illegals, who knew about their parents crimes and did not report them.

There are good places like Arizona and Alabama that have very shortsighted and
mean political leadership which has put these states in a bind, both ethically
and practically. Florida need not go there and their good Cuban American citizens will certainly prevent it and quiet down their know nothing governor.

When you reward bad behavior with benefits you will get more bad behavior. Do you reward a dog with a special treat when it tears holes in your carpet? Why would you reward the children of illegal aliens with subsidized education? They are not residents of the state if they are not legally in the state.

Get rid of state universities and fewer people will become college educated -- because of the high tuition charged by private universities.  How could having fewer educated people make Florida 'more inviting to industry"?

Sara:  I'm not sure your sons are ineligible to run for President.  (Why would they want to, but that's another question.)  Although it is an unsettled issue, your sons would seem to be "natural-born" (i.e., automatically citizens from birth, because of the circumstances of their birth, with no need to explicitly apply for citizenship), as opposed to persons who were not citizens from birth and had to apply for citizenship and go through the naturalization process (five-year residency period, taking a civics test, taking an oath, etc.).

Sir/Madam with all due respect you have no idea what you are talking about. "Anchor" baby is a term thrown around by people who are ignorant on immigration laws. In order for a US citizen child to petition for his/her parents, a whole list of requirements must be met. Even then, it takes at least 21 years until the "anchor baby" is able to petition for his parents, if they even qualify. If you do not think that after 21 years of living in the United States, abiding by all laws, never been in jail, paying taxes does not grant you the right to hold legal residency in this country then we ought to look at all the expats living lavishly in Europe, taking non-resident credits and enjoying US citizen rights, only because they were born here.

Skin color has nothing to do with being here illegally. If you weren't born here and came from another country without the proper documentation, you are illegal. If your grandparents did not have papers, you would still be able to pass the test that this law requires. It is the first generation children that are affected by this law.

Francis; racism does not run deep. Respect for the written law runs deep. Why should we provide citizenship or special dispensation for someone that comes into the country illegally? Do you reward a dog that digs holes in your new carpet with a special treat?

In some communities in California law enforcement is prohibited from impounding and towing the car of an illegal alien because it would cause them financial harm and preventing them from going to work. If it is illegal for them to be here and it is illegal to employ them and they do not have a license to drive, why should they get special status and keep their car when a citizen driving without a license gets the car towed?

Equal enforcement of the law is needed. We are granted Equal Protection under the law, now we need equal enforcement.

If you cannot prove your parents were citizens then perhaps you should not live in Florida where this law is in effect. There are several states, like California that you can live with impunity even if you are illegal. They encourage them to come to California with large payments of Welfare without proof of citizenship. That is part of why they have so many budget overruns. If you are illegal in California you can also get student loans. then after graduation you can just get another social security number, change your name and go to a different state where you can use your false ID and get a job with your shiny new degree and not pay back the school loans.

What part of the word "Illegal" are you confused about? If the parents are not here with legal status then they are not citizens and are therefore not residents. If they are not residents of the state, they are required to pay higher tuition rates than residents. They can move to California where illegals pay the same as residents and can also get state loans to go to school. Move to California, easy solution. They love the illegals there and even pay welfare benefits to them.

Marge and Claire, if the parents are not citizens then they cannot be residents of the state. If the parents are not residents the children cannot be residents either.

They are free to move to California or Texas where illegals get in-state tuition. California even gives them loans for college and will pay the illegal parents welfare benefits.

I know this to be true because I just moved away from there. this was one of the MANY reasons.
the sooner the illegals leave, the sooner we can get the construction jobs back for the citizens that live here and are out of work.
